questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.answer: One of the limitations of using money is that it does not allow for the transfer of purchasing power into the future.
When money is used as a yardstick to describe the price of various goods and services, it serves as a store of value.
The necessary condition required for money to function as a medium of exchange is that it also needs to be a store of value.
The hours of labor that go into producing a product are a better unit of account than paper money.

questions.question: If the growth rate of nominal GDP and the rate of inflation in an economy are 4% and 1% respectively, the growth rate of real GDP in the economy must be:
The quantity theory of money implies that:

choices.answer: inflation is equal to the gap between the growth rate of money supply and the current real interest rates.
inflation is equal to the gap between the growth rate of money supply and the current nominal interest rates.
inflation is equal to the gap between the growth rate of money supply and the growth rate of real GDP.
inflation is equal to the gap between the growth rate of money supply and the growth rate of nominal GDP.

questions.question: Assuming all else equal, inflation can:

choices.answer: reduce the real interest rate, and increase the real wage rate.
increase both the real interest rate and the real wage rate.
reduce both the real interest rate and the real wage rate.
increase the real interest rate, and reduce the real wage rate.

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to happen when the Fed lowers the federal funds rate?

choices.answer: The long-run interest rate will increase.
The volume of economic activity will decrease.
The labor demand curve shifts to the left.
The labor demand curve shifts to the right.

questions.question: Assuming all else equal, if there is a contraction in the quantity of bank account balances, it will cause:

choices.answer: a downward movement along the demand curve for reserves.
a rightward shift in the demand curve for reserves.
a leftward shift in the demand curve for reserves.
an upward movement along the demand curve for reserves.

questions.question: If the Fed purchases government bonds in the open market, it will cause:

choices.answer: a shift of the supply curve for reserves to the left.
an upward movement along the supply curve for reserves.
a downward movement along the supply curve for reserves.
a shift of the supply curve for reserves to the right.

questions.question: If there is a change in the federal funds rate from a target rate due to an increase in the demand for reserves, the Fed can maintain the target by:

choices.answer: causing the supply curve of reserves to shift to the left.
causing the supply curve of reserves to shift to the right.
causing an upward movement along the supply of reserves curve.
causing a downward movement along the supply of reserves curve.

questions.question: If the realized real interest rate in an economy is $6 \%$, the realized inflation rate is $8 \%$, and the expected inflation rate is $8 \%$, then the nominal interest rate in the economy is:
If there are no changes in inflation expectations, a purchase of government bonds by the Fed in the open market will cause ______.

choices.answer: the federal funds rate to fall and the long-run expected real interest rate to rise
both the federal funds rate and long-run expected real interest rate to fall
the federal funds rate to rise and the long-run expected real interest rate to fall
both the federal funds rate and long-run expected real interest rate to rise

choices.answer: Co-movement of many aggregate macroeconomic variables

choices.answer: There will be an upward movement along the labor demand curve.

choices.answer: Many people stopped paying their motgages

A decline in money supply will lead to a(n) ________ if nominal wages are rigid.

choices.answer: Countercyclical monetary policy stimulates the economy during a recession by shifting the labor demand curve to the left.
Countercyclical fiscal policy stimulates the economy during a recession by shifting the labor demand curve to the left.
Countercyclical monetary policy slows down the growth rate of an economy during an expansion by shifting the labor demand curve to the right.

questions.question:
Why would policymakers target a reduction in GDP growth by using contractionary policies?

i) The Fed fights inflation by increasing interest rates, which in turn causes a reduction in employment as a by-product.

ii) Excessive optimistic sentiments about the economy can result in an unsustainable economic expansion.

choices.answer: i) is true and ii) is false
i) and ii) are both false
i) and ii) are both true
i) is false and ii) is true

questions.question: If the long-run real interest rate falls, ________.
________ occurs when the Fed creates a large amount of reserves to buy long-term bonds from banks.

choices.answer: every percentage point increase in the nominal interest rate increases the federal funds rate by half a percentage point
every percentage point increase in the inflation rate increases the federal funds rate by $1.5$ percentage points
every percentage point increase in the nominal interest rate decreases the federal funds rate by half a percentage point
every percentage point increase in the inflation rate decreases the federal funds rate by 1.5 percentage points

choices.answer: An increase in interest rates due to a decrease in investment
An increase in government expenditure in unemployment benefits
A decrease in inflation due to an increase in consumption
An decrease in money supply due to a decrease in bank deposits

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a expansionary fiscal policy during a recession?

choices.answer: A reduction in public assistance programs
A decrease in money supply to lower the federal funds rate
An increase in tax rates to increase revenue
A temporary tax cut to boost consumption

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to be true when the economy is in a boom?

choices.answer: The size of government expenditure multiplier is large.
The size of government expenditure multiplier is small.

questions.question: If the value of a government-taxation multiplier is 1.8, which of the following is likely to be true if  all other variables remain unchanged?

choices.answer: A $\$ 1$ reduction in taxation increases gross domestic product by $\$ 1.80$.
A $\$ 1$ increase in taxation increases gross domestic product by $\$ 1.80$.
A $\$ 1.80$ reduction in taxation increases gross domestic product by $\$ 1.80$.
A $\$ 1.80$ increase in taxation increases gross domestic product by $\$ 1.80$.

questions.question:
Consider two economies, Beta and Zeta. Each farmer in Beta can grow 1,000 pounds of apples in a year or 500 pounds of oranges. Each farmer in Zeta can grow 400 pounds of apples or 1,200 pounds of oranges in a year.

choices.answer: Zeta has absolute advantage in producing apples.
Beta has a comparative advantage in producing apples.

Zeta has an comparative advantage in producing apples.

questions.question:

choices.answer: Beta has a comparative advantage in producing oranges.
Zeta has an comparative advantage in producing apples.

questions.question:

choices.answer: Zeta has an absolute advantage in producing both oranges and apples.

choices.answer: will cause the dollars to appreciate against the pesos and will decrease the quantity of dollars being traded in the foreign exchange market.

will cause the dollars to depreciate against the pesos and will decrease the quantity of dollars being traded in the foreign exchange market.

choices.answer: the dollar is worth less of that currency than it would have been under a fixed exchange rate regime.

choices.answer: quantity of dollar supplied in exchange of pesos equals the quantity of dollars demanded in exchange of pesos in the foreign exchange market.
the exchange rate between the dollar and the peso is flexible.

choices.answer: the real exchange rate depreciates even when the nominal exchange rate is constant.

the real exchange rate depreciates only when the nominal exchange rate depreciates.

choices.answer: its currency will initially appreciate and then depreciate.

questions.question: How would a government with a fixed nominal exchange rate defend an undervalued currency?

choices.answer: To defend the currency, the domestic government has to buy the foreign currency and sell the domestic currency.
To defend the currency, the domestic government has to sell the foreign currency and buy the domestic currency.
To defend the currency, the domestic government has to buy the foreign and the domestic currency.
To defend the currency, the domestic government has to sell the foreign and the domestic currency.

questions.question: In economics, scarcity refers to the situation of:

choices.answer: Optimizing with the use of limited information.
Having more wants than the amount of available resources.
Sellers setting the prices of their products too high for people to be able to afford them.
Rationing of available goods and services by the government.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly defines the term "equilibrium"?

choices.answer: It refers to a situation where all agents are simultaneously optimizing.
It refers to government intervention that efficiently allocates scarce resources.
It refers to an optimizing decision made by an individual economic agent.
It refers to analysis that uses data to arrive at conclusions.

Maria has to choose between driving and taking a train to destination A. Traveling by train will cost her \$400 and will take 4 hours. Driving to destination A takes 6 hours, and the required amount of gasoline costs \$250. Her opportunity cost of time is \$15 per hour.

travel by train, because it is quicker.

questions.question: Empiricism refers to the process of:

choices.answer: making choices using values and beliefs.

questions.question: Which of the following statements identifies a difference between correlation and causation?

choices.answer: Correlation occurs when one thing directly affects another, whereas causation implies a mutual relationship between two things.
Causation cannot arise when correlation is present, and correlation cannot arise when causation is present.
A causal relationship exists between two variables when they are correlated, but correlation does not necessarily exist if there's a causal relationship between two variables.
Correlation implies a mutual relationship between two things, whereas causation occurs when one thing directly affects another.

choice, rather than by chance; treatment group or into a control group.
chance, rather than by choice; treatment group or into a control group.

choices.answer: The net benefit of Project A is $5.

questions.question:
Sarah has to choose between renting a hotel room for two days and renting a hotel room for three days.

choices.answer: An optimizer will rent the hotel room for three days if the benefit of staying for the third day exceeds the benefits of staying for the first two days.

$, where $Z$ is a standard normal random variable.

questions.question:
A dietary supplement company plans to launch a product aimed at improving cholesterol levels. The supplement contains natural ingredients known for their cholesterol-lowering effects. Concerns arise about potential muscle cramps and spasms as adverse effects. To investigate, researchers conducted a six-month experiment with randomly assigned volunteers to the placebo or supplement group. Discomfort and pain levels are assessed through questions at the study's start (before taking supplement or placebo) and at the end (after six-months of using the supplement or placebo). A simple first step hypothesis is designed to test if the average difference in discomfort or pain scores
(D = $PAIN_{\text{END}} - PAIN_{\text{START}}$) for the supplement group is greater than 0

What is a Type I error in the scenario of the simple hypothesis and what are the negative consequences for the dietary supplement company if the hypothesis test results in a Type I error?

choices.answer:
A Type I error would mean concluding that the dietary ssupplement does increase discomfort or pain when there is no actual increase in discomfort or pain associated with the dietary
supplement. The negative consequences for the dietary supplement company if the hypothesis test results in a Type I error could include loss of a viable product, loss of potential profits, and money spent researching the product

A Type I error would mean concluding that the dietary supplement has a significant effect on reducing discomfort or pain when it does not. The negative consequences for the dietary supplement company if the hypothesis test results in a Type I error could include loss of consumer trust, and damaged reputation.

A Type I error would mean concluding that the dietary supplement has a significant effect on improving cholesterol levels when it does not. The negative consequences for the dietary supplement company if the hypothesis test results in a Type I error could include loss of consumer trust, and damaged reputation

A Type I error would mean concluding that the dietary supplement does not have a significant effect on improving cholesterol levels when it does. The negative consequences for the dietary supplement company if the hypothesis test results in a Type I error could include loss of a viable product, loss of potential profits, and time spent researching the product.

A Type I error would mean concluding that the dietary supplement does not have a significant effect on reducing discomfort or pain when it does. The negative consequences for the dietary supplement company if the hypothesis test results in a Type I error could include loss of a viable product, loss of potential profits, and money spent researching the product.

questions.question:
A major source of profit for a new video streaming company, YouCube, is the advertisements that are played before their videos begin. The company charges their ad clients a rate per second watched. Therefore, it is of importance for YouCube to find out how long the users are willing to wait, in seconds, before the “Skip Ad” option appears on screen. To determine this information, the first 400 newly registered users were chosen. Then the company randomly assigned 4, 5, 6, or 7 seconds to wait for the “Skip Ad” option to appear on the screen for each user. Thus, each group has 100 participants. After one month, they will record the activity score of each user, ranging between 1 and 10, which reflects how active the user is on the platform at the moment of recording. 

(B) Is this an observational study or an experiment? Please explain your answer.

(C) State one lurking variable in this scenario. Be sure to state whether it is confounding or common response.

choices.answer:
(B) experiment. Reason: The company is assigning the number of seconds until the “Skip Ad” option appears.   

(C) Why the users are watching the videos What type of videos are being watched Are there are there other platforms that the users could watch the videos The ads themselves: content/quality, etc.  State one.

(E) Interpret the appropriate 97.5% confidence interval or bound mentioned in part (D) Please include at least three decimal places for the appropriate number(s). Also state the number of
the appropriate output used. 

(F) Based on your answer for part (E), what would the decision be for the appropriate hypothesis test for the hypotheses stated in part (C)? Please explain your answer.
 ![Chart](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/MArY5gBGDDml3OLXW4ZWD)
![Outputs](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/Mzs-gWInr06ra3VCku__E)

choices.answer:
(E) We are 97.5% confident that the difference between the population or true mean or average FID between the algorithmic modification and the standard algorithm (M - S) is less than the upper bound of 0.2712962. 

(F) Confidence level of 97.5% and the significance of 2.5% add up to 100% and the null value of 0 is contained in the interval so we would fail to reject.

questions.question:
In Computer Assignment #5b you explored the relationship of Type I ($\alpha$) and Type II error ($\beta$), Power ($1 - \beta$), sample size ($n$), the standard deviation ($\sigma$), and the choice of an alternative mean value ($\mu_a$) for a one-sample test of the population mean. You were asked to explore graphically what value of the sample size was required for the Type II error to be equivalent to the specified significance level (Type I error) for a given alternative $\mu_a$. Suppose we want to test the following hypothesis:

$H_0$: $\mu \geq 76$

$H_a$: $\mu < 76$

We will sample from a population that is known to be normally distributed with a standard deviation of $\sigma = 16$. We will require control of the Type I error at a level $\alpha = 0.02$ and require the Type II error to also be $\beta = 0.02$ for an alternative of $\mu_a = 60$. Determine the sample size required to ensure that the Type I error and Type II error probabilities are equal ($\alpha = \beta$).

(a) Select the correct code and output for determining the 𝒛 critical value (quantile) that forms the rejection region boundary of the standardized distribution. Is the correct value (A) or (B)?

(b) Determine a formula for 𝒙̅ 𝐜𝐮𝐭𝐨𝐟𝐟 with respect to the null value $\mu_{0}$.

 ![Bell Curve ](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/HhvS0VQwIkkjAggKm5BFf)
![Values](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/C8TDXnT9I3C0sbL18Mjm5)

choices.answer:
(a) (A)  

(b) 𝑷(𝐓𝐲𝐩𝐞 𝐈 𝐄𝐫𝐫𝐨𝐫) = 𝟎.𝟎𝟐 𝑷(𝑿 ̅ < 𝒙̅𝐜𝐮𝐭𝐨𝐟𝐟|𝝁 = 𝝁𝟎) = 𝟎.𝟎𝟐 𝑷(𝒁 < −𝟐.𝟎𝟓𝟑𝟕𝟒) = 𝟎.𝟎𝟐  and 𝑷(𝒁 < 𝒙 ̅𝐜𝐮𝐭𝐨𝐟𝐟−𝝁𝟎 𝝈/√𝒏 𝒙 ) =𝟎.𝟎𝟐 ̅𝐜𝐮𝐭𝐨𝐟𝐟 − 𝟕𝟔 =−𝟐.𝟎𝟓𝟑𝟕𝟒 (B) > z <- qnorm(0.02/2, lower.tail = FALSE) > z [1] 2.326348 𝟏𝟔/√𝒏̅𝐜𝐮𝐭𝐨𝐟𝐟 = −𝟐.𝟎𝟓𝟑𝟕𝟒 × 𝟏𝟔 +𝟕𝟔 𝒙 √𝒏

questions.question:
In Computer Assignment #5b you explored the relationship of Type I (𝜶) and Type II error (𝜷), Power (𝟏−𝜷), sample size (𝒏), the standard deviation (𝝈), and the choice of an alternative mean value (𝝁𝒂) for a one-sample test of the population mean. You were asked to explore graphically what value of the sample size was required for the Type II error to be equivalent to the specified significance level (Type I error) for a given alternative 𝝁𝒂. Suppose we want to test the following hypothesis: 𝐇𝟎:𝝁 ≥ 𝟕𝟔 𝐇𝐚:𝝁 < 𝟕𝟔 We will sample from a population that is known to be normally distributed with a standard deviation of 𝝈 =𝟏𝟔. We will require control of the Type I error at a level 𝜶 = 𝟎.𝟎𝟐 and require the Type II error to also be 𝜷 = 𝟎.𝟎𝟐 for an alternative of 𝝁𝒂 = 𝟔𝟎. Determine the sample size required to ensure that the Type I error and Type I error probabilities are equal (𝜶 = 𝜷). 

(c) Write an expression for the probability of Type II error using 𝒙̅ 𝐜𝐮𝐭𝐨𝐟𝐟 in the probability statement.

(d) Standardize 𝒙̅ 𝐜𝐮𝐭𝐨𝐟𝐟 with respect to the alternative and equate the value to appropriate 𝒛 critical value (quantile). (Hint think about the standardized graphs.)

(e) Solve your equation for the sample size and obtain the minimal sample size required to ensure that the Type I error and Type I error probabilities are equal (𝜶 = 𝜷) for the given alternative of 𝝁𝒂 = 𝟔𝟎.

 ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/w6NVuWUY1oG5atG16woy6)
![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/HnfB3ais_J79g92ZFHqof)

A one sample test statistic $T = \frac{\bar{X} - \mu_0}{S/\sqrt{n}}$ defines a procedure for assessing the consistency of the data with that of the null hypothesis and we evaluate this evidence using a $p$-value.

True or False? The $p$-value associated with the test statistic $T = \frac{\bar{X} - \mu_0}{S/\sqrt{n}}$ can also be considered a random variable.

In two distinct studies, two researchers obtained a sample of size \( n = 11 \) from their respective populations both known to be normally distributed. In study 1, the researcher has knowledge of the population standard deviation, while in study 2, the researcher lacks knowledge of the population standard deviation, and it must be estimated. Both studies aim to construct a 98% confidence interval. 

True or False? The critical value \( t^* \) used to construct the confidence interval in study 2 will be larger than that of the critical value \( z^* \) used in study 1.

In a survey to ascertain the favored presidential candidate among eligible U.S. voters, the nation's electoral college system plays a pivotal role, reflecting the preferences of individual states. As part of this study, 500 random registered voters from each state are polled about their voting choices. 

True or False? The sampling design employed in this survey is stratified random sampling.

In a consumer study evaluating the taste preferences of different coffee blends, researchers are investigating the influence of various factors, including coffee roast level (light, medium, dark), brewing method (drip, French press, espresso), and the coffee beans' country of origin (Colombia, Ethiopia, Brazil). One factor that is beyond the researchers' control is the participants' experience with coffee (occasional coffee drinker, daily coffee drinker, coffee enthusiasts). This diversity in coffee experience could introduce variability into the study. To address this potential source of variability, the researcher decides to conduct a randomized block design experiment. 

True or False? In this scenario, the blocks of the randomized block design would include all combinations of coffee roast level, brewing method, coffee beans’ country of origin, and participant’s experience level with coffee.

The power associated with a statistical hypothesis test is stated to be 95%. 

True or False? This indicates that the test has a 95% probability of correctly rejecting the null hypothesis when the alternative hypothesis is true.

A clinical trial was conducted which obtained statistical significance. The effect size was measured to be 0.19. 

True or False? Since the effect size was measured to be small, we would conclude the results to not be practically significant, regardless of the potential impacts of the study.
Which of the following statements is accurate regarding hypothesis tests?

choices.answer: Type I Error can be considered as the rejection of the null hypothesis when the alternative hypothesis is true.
Power can be considered as the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis in favor of the alternative when the alternative is false.
When the probability of Type II Error decreases, power increases.
Type II Error can be considered as the rejection of the null hypothesis when the null hypothesis is true.

questions.question: In a pharmaceutical study to develop a new pain relief medication, researchers investigate two factors: dosage, and administration method. Dosage has three levels: low (50 mg), medium (100 mg), and high (150 mg) dosages and the administration method also has three levels: oral tablets, injectable solution, and transdermal patch. The response variable is the pain relief score (1 to 10). How many treatment groups result from the combinations of these factors?
In a statistical study, which of the following statements correctly describes the relationship between confidence interval, margin of error, sample size, and confidence level?

choices.answer: While keeping the confidence level constant, increasing the sample size decreases the margin of error, which narrows the confidence interval
Increasing the sample size increases the confidence level, which narrows the confidence interval and reduces the margin of error.
While keeping the confidence level constant, increasing the sample size increases the margin of error, which widens the confidence interval.
Increasing the sample size decreases the confidence level, which widens the confidence interval and reduces the margin of error.

questions.question:
The local environmental task force is conducting a study to estimate the average CO2 emissions in hectograms per mile (hectogram/mi) of vehicles in a city. A simple random sample of 22 vehicles was taken, and the data is collected. The task force is interested in making inferences about the population mean CO2 emissions. The following graphs were generated from the above sample.

(A) Using the above provided figures, what specific assumption(s) about the data can be tested to ensure the validity of performing statistical inference regarding the population mean CO2 emission of vehicles in a city? Please explain your answer and assess whether these assumptions are met based on the provided graphs. Be clear about what information is conveyed in each graph

(B) If the assumptions mentioned in (A) are not met, how could you adjust the data, to potentially satisfy these assumptions? If your answer to (A) is affirmative regarding the assumptions, specify any additional assumptions required for the analysis that cannot be determined from the graphs alone and explain how you would verify their validity. ![Histogram ](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/9tSSlsEPb0SYrlcF_kTbW)
![Normal Probability Plot](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/jOJAk6C18Z5dQ3Kpuqid5)

choices.answer:
(A) The histogram and normal probability plots of the sample CO2 emission measurements both provide insights into the possible shape of the population CO2 emissions in the city and allow us to check whether the normality assumption is reasonable.  Considering that the sample size is 22 any strong deviations from normality can be problematic. The histogram is clearly positively skewed and not a symmetric distribution. This same behavior is confirmed in the normal probability plot points above the line at the ends and below the line in the middle. Since the data is moderately positively skewed the assumption of normality is not valid. 

(B) Assumptions not met: We can possibly transform the CO2 emissions using a log transformation. Applying the log transformation can make the data become closer to a normal distribution.

questions.question:
A company exclusively employs 22-inch cube-shaped boxes for its shipping requirements. To negotiate a favorable shipping rate, it is crucial for the company to ascertain the average weight of the filled boxes. There was a prevailing belief that the mean weight of these boxes was approximately 50 pounds. However, the executive responsible for negotiating the shipping rates held the opinion that the mean weight was greater than 50 pounds. To further investigate this matter, the executive selected a sample of 45 boxes. The sample yielded a mean weight of 50.0381 pounds and a sample standard deviation of 0.1083 pounds. The results of various statistical tests are provided in the R output on the last page.

Does the data offer any evidence supporting the claim made by the executive?
Using the above information and the information contained on the last page of the exam perform a four-step hypothesis test with a significance level 𝜶 = 𝟎. 𝟎𝟗.  

(A) Specify which output from the last page of the exam was used to obtain to obtain your conclusions. 

(B) Calculate an appropriate confidence interval or bound that corresponds to the hypothesis test conducted in part (A). State if you are using a confidence interval or bound and be sure to mention the confidence level used for this interval or bound. Clearly specify which output from the last page of the exam was used to obtain to obtain your conclusions.

(C) Interpret the result obtained in part (B) within the context of the problem. ![Part A outputs ](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/HOpZMG7JwTX4njLMltdGR)
![Part B output](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/wuJEPqjf7suyXseGhWsjl)

choices.answer:
(A) Output 6
 Let 𝝁𝐁𝐨𝐱 denote the mean weight of boxes filled at this company for shipping. 𝑯𝟎:𝝁𝐁𝐨𝐱 ≤ 𝟓𝟎  𝑯𝒂:𝝁𝐁𝐨𝐱 > 𝟓𝟎 𝐝𝐟 = 𝟒𝟓−𝟏=𝟒𝟒 𝐓𝐓𝐒 = 𝟐.𝟑𝟓𝟗𝟓 𝒑-value = 𝟎.𝟎𝟏𝟏𝟒 . Decision: 𝒑-value = 𝟎.𝟎𝟏𝟏𝟒 < 𝟎.𝟎𝟗 reject the null hypothesis. Conclusion: The data does provide some evidence (𝒑-value = 𝟎.𝟎𝟏𝟏𝟒) to the claim that the population average weight of the filled boxes is greater than 50 pounds at this company. 

(B) Confidence lower bound is appropriate since the alternative hypothesis is “>”.  Appropriate confidence level is 𝟏𝟎𝟎×(𝟏−𝜶)%=𝟗𝟏%.   Critical Value: > qt(0.09, df, lower.tail = FALSE) [1] 1.362417    Lower Confidence Bound:  𝒙 ̅−𝒕∗ 𝒔 √𝒏 =𝟓𝟎.𝟎𝟑𝟖𝟏−𝟏.𝟑𝟔𝟐𝟒𝟏𝟕×𝟎.𝟏𝟎𝟖𝟑 √𝟒𝟓 =𝟓𝟎.𝟎𝟏𝟔𝟏 

(C) We are 91% confident that the true mean weight of boxes is more than the 91% confidence lower bound of 50.0161.

questions.question:
A group of dietitians conducted a study to investigate the impact of consuming pasta with
and without a source of protein on the post-meal rise in blood sugar levels. They collected an SRS of 50 participants and randomly assigned each to either group 1 or group 2, until one group reached the size of 25. The remaining participants were assigned to the other group.
During the experiment, all the participants were on an identical, strictly controlled diet for one week. At the end of the week, Group 1 was given a meal consisting of pasta with an additional source of protein, and group 2 was given the same pasta dish without any additional source of protein. Blood sugar levels were measured for each participant both before and after the meal, and the differences (“after” minus “before” measured in milligrams per deciliter, mg/dL) were recorded. The summary statistics are shown in the table below. 

(A) Considering the study's objectives and the method of data collection, which statistical methodology, between two-sample independent and two-sample paired, would be more suitable for analysis? Provide your reasoning.
 ![Chart](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/yuUDs9LC2-4OA23M1DIEo)

choices.answer:
Two-sample independent is appropriate as there is nothing to match one person from Group 1
to another person in Group 2. Though each group shares the same pasta dish this is not a
factor to match units on as it is the same for all with the only difference being the protein/lack of
protein. Additionally, the sample units for Group 1 are selected independently of those from
Group 2.

questions.question:
In a semiconductor manufacturing company, the production process for microchips relies on a critical component that plays a vital role in the chips' performance. Even small deviations in these dimensions can lead to substantial losses. The company has a well-established process for producing these components and has been measuring the standard deviation of this critical dimension for years, obtaining a very precise estimate of 𝝈 = 𝟐 nm (nano meter). It is also known that the critical dimension of these components follows a normal distribution.
The company is considering implementing an improved lithography technique in the manufacturing process that is expected to make the components even more precise, leading to a smaller critical dimension. However, implementing this change is extremely costly, and there is a lot at stake. They need to be sure that the improvement will result in a smaller critical dimension before investing in the
new lithography technique. The current critical dimension is measured to be on average 22 nm and for the new technique to be worth the investment they need to have an average reduction of 2 nm to justify the investment in the new lithography technique to their stake holders. A study is to be conducted in which the Type I error rate is to be controlled at a significance level 𝜶 = 𝟎. 𝟎𝟎𝟏. Additionally, the study requires a high degree of power to detect a reduction of 2nm or more. The team working on the improved lithography technique is granted enough resources to manufacture 35 components for testing this hypothesis. Is a sample size of 𝒏 = 𝟑𝟓 enough to identify a reduction of 2nm at a high degree of power?

(A) Clearly state the parameter of interest and define the null and the alternative
hypothesis of the study.
 ![Part B Outputs ](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/drj7loYrFBBsEnkCpmq5B)
![Part C Outputs](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/6dQEeoVy9sIR1UeCxxH_E)

The parameter of interest would be the true average reduction in the critical dimension 𝝁𝑫.  𝑫=𝐍𝐞𝐰 𝐌𝐨𝐝𝐢𝐟𝐢𝐞𝐝 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐜𝐞𝐬𝐬- 𝐎𝐫𝐢𝐠𝐢𝐧𝐚𝐥 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐜𝐞𝐬𝐬. 𝑯𝟎:𝝁𝑫≥𝟎 𝑯𝒂:𝝁𝑫<𝟎  or   𝑫 =𝐎𝐫𝐢𝐠𝐢𝐧𝐚𝐥 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐜𝐞𝐬𝐬- 𝐍𝐞𝐰 𝐌𝐨𝐝𝐢𝐟𝐢𝐞𝐝 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐜𝐞𝐬𝐬. 𝑯𝟎:𝝁𝑫≥𝟎 𝑯𝒂:𝝁𝑫<𝟎

questions.question:
In a semiconductor manufacturing company, the production process for microchips relies on a critical component that plays a vital role in the chips' performance. Even small deviations in these dimensions can lead to substantial losses. The company has a well-established process for producing these components and has been measuring the standard deviation of this critical dimension for years, obtaining a very precise estimate of 𝝈=𝟐 nm (nano meter). It is also known that the critical dimension of these components follows a normal distribution.  The company is considering implementing an improved lithography technique in the manufacturing process that is expected to make the components even more precise, leading to a smaller critical dimension. However, implementing this change is extremely costly, and there is a lot at stake. They need to be sure that the improvement will result in a smaller critical dimension before investing in the new lithography technique.   The current critical dimension is measured to be on average 22 nm and for the new technique to be worth the investment they need to have an average reduction of 2 nm to justify the investment in the new lithography technique to their stake holders. A study is to be conducted in which the Type I error rate is to be controlled at a significance level 𝜶=𝟎.𝟎𝟎𝟏. Additionally, the study requires a high degree of power to detect a reduction of 2nm or more. The team working on the improved lithography technique is granted enough resources to manufacture 35 components for testing this hypothesis. Is a sample size of 𝒏=𝟑𝟓 enough to identify a reduction of 2nm at a high degree of power? 

(C)  Utilize the cutoff value calculated in part (b) to calculate the power associated with detecting a decrease in the critical dimension by 2nm. Clearly show the mathematical steps required to obtain the power of the test and select the correct code and output for computing the power of this test from the table.   ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/AcSWYY3Gp4cVmUvm4bUfO)

choices.answer:
1) One Sample Procedure: Computing Power: 𝑷(𝑿 ̅ < 𝟐𝟎.𝟗𝟓𝟓𝟑𝟏|𝝁 = 𝝁𝒂) = 𝟏−𝜷  Standardize with respect to the required alternative 𝝁𝒂 = 𝟐𝟐 − 𝟐 = 𝟐𝟎. 𝑷(𝑿 ̅ < 𝟐𝟎.𝟗𝟓𝟓𝟑𝟏−𝟐𝟎 ) =𝑷(𝒁<𝟐.𝟖𝟐𝟓𝟖𝟒𝟓)  =  0.9976422

2) Computing Power: 𝑷(𝑿 ̅𝑫 < −𝟏.𝟎𝟒𝟒𝟔𝟖𝟗|𝝁 = 𝝁𝒂) = 𝟏−𝜷  𝑷(𝑿 ̅𝑫 > 𝟏.𝟎𝟒𝟒𝟔𝟖𝟗|𝝁 = 𝝁𝒂) = 𝟏−𝜷  
Standardize with respect to the required alternative 𝝁𝒂 = −𝟐 or 𝝁𝒂 = 𝟐. 𝑷(𝑿 ̅𝑫 < −𝟏.𝟎𝟒𝟒𝟔𝟖𝟗+𝟐 ) =𝑷(𝒁<𝟐.𝟖𝟐𝟓𝟖𝟒𝟖) 𝟐/√𝟑𝟓 𝑷(𝑿 ̅𝑫 > 𝟏.𝟎𝟒𝟒𝟔𝟖𝟗−𝟐 𝟐/√𝟑𝟓 ) =𝑷(𝒁>−𝟐.𝟖𝟐𝟓𝟖𝟒𝟖) =  0.9976422

questions.question:
A two-sample independent analysis is conducted by a researcher who decides to use the pooled estimator of the variance to construct a 95% confidence interval for the difference in means between population A and population B. Unbeknownst to the researcher, the variances of these populations follow the relationship $\sigma_{A}^{2} = 25 \times \sigma_{B}^{2}. $

A. If the confidence interval is built using a sample from population A of size $n_{A} = 825$ and from population B with size, $n_{B} = 46$, what can be said about the width of the confidence interval and the true coverage probability of the confidence interval? The formula for the pooled estimate of the variance is given below as $s_{p}^{2}$. Type the answer choice in a capitalized form. 

$s_{p}^{2} = \left( \frac{n_{A} - 1}{n_{A} + n_{B} - 2} \right) s_{A}^{2} + \left( \frac{n_{B} - 1}{n_{A} + n_{B} - 2} \right) s_{B}^{2}$

(A) It is wide enough to capture the true mean difference $\mu_{A} - \mu_{B}$
exactly 95% of the time that this procedure is performed.

(B)  It is the same as the width of a 95% confidence interval that is constructed without pooling.

(C) It is narrower than expected on average, capturing the true mean difference $\mu_{A} - \mu_{B}$ less than 95% of the time that this procedure is performed.

(D) It is wider than expected on average, capturing the true mean difference $\mu_{A} - \mu_{B}$ more than 95% of the time that this procedure is performed.

B. For a two-independent sample procedure, provide a scenario where using the pooled estimator may be advantageous. Explain why this approach is beneficial in that particular situation.

choices.answer:
1. (D) 

2. The pooled estimator is advantageous when 𝝈𝑨 𝟐 = 𝝈𝑩 𝟐. The reason it can be advantageous is that we can pool both source information from samples from A and samples from B to estimate the same quantity and pool the information together. Such situations we get a more efficient estimator than the non-pooled estimator

A university is studying the relationship between the amount of investment in server facilities to the average server traffic. The research team obtained the following set of graphics from their data of 100 pairs, collected from an SRS of other universities with servers of varying sizes.

(a) List ALL assumptions which should be satisfied to conduct inference in a simple linear regression analysis. ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/8p0L-KWKlKdt6tLCR_1h_)

choices.answer:
Assumptions:
1) SRS: The response (server traffic) is obtained as a simple random sample for each
fixed 𝒙 (investment). It is okay if they mention that the pairs are SRS.
2) Linearity: Assume that the relationship between server traffic and investment dollars
is linear.
3) Homogeneity/Constant Variance: Assume that the residual errors have common
variance.
4) Normality: Assume that the residual errors are normally distribued.

questions.question:
A university is studying the relationship between the amount of investment in server facilities to the average server traffic. The research team obtained the following set of graphics from their data of 100 pairs, collected from an SRS of other universities with servers of varying sizes.

choices.answer:
1) SRS: Is assumed true as stated in the problem description. (Valid)
2) Linearity: Curvature clearly visible. (Invalid)
graphs: Scatter Plot: Curvature of points &  Residual Plot: Curvature of points
3) Homogeneity/Constant Variance: Variability is low for small values (below 20) and high for large
values (above 20). (Invalid)
graphs: Scatter Plot: Concentration of Points &  Residual Plot: Concentration of Points
4) Normality: The residuals are positively skewed and have outliers. (Invalid)
graphs: Histogram of Residuals: Gaps in histogram indicate outliers and long right tail. Blue
normal curve and red kernel curve do not align. &  Normal Probability Plot of Residuals: Concave up and points do not follow the line.

The net interaction with other objects in universe may be not zero, but it is constant in time
The object does not obey laws of physics
There is no gravity acting on that object

He then catches a $160 \mathrm{~g}$ puck flying at speed $\langle 40, 20, 2 \rangle \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ ($z$-axis is vertical).

What is the momentum of the player before he catches the puck?

He then catches a $160 \mathrm{~g}$ puck flying at speed $\langle 40, 20, 2 \rangle \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ ($z$-axis is vertical).

What is the velocity of the player after he catches the puck? Note that the guy still slides along horizontal surface of the ice.

He then catches a $160 \mathrm{~g}$ puck flying at speed $\langle 40, 20, 2 \rangle \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ ($z$-axis is vertical).

What is the change in the momentum of the guy?

He then catches a $160 \mathrm{~g}$ puck flying at speed $\langle 40, 20, 2 \rangle \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ ($z$-axis is vertical).

What is the change in the momentum of the puck?

An unstable Pu-240 nucleus (mass $240.002 \mathrm{~u}$) is at rest when it fissions into two Ag-120 nuclei (mass $119.893 \mathrm{~u}$) which then fly off far from each other. Find the final kinetic energy of one Ag-120 nucleus when it is far from the other one. $\left(1 \mathrm{~u}=1\right.$ atomic mass unit $\left.=1.66 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~kg}\right)$

When a falling object reaches terminal speed, its kinetic energy reaches a constant value. However, the gravitational potential energy of the system consisting of the object, Earth and atmosphere continues to decrease. Which of the following best describes why this is not a violation of the conservation of energy for the system consisting of the object plus the Earth?

choices.answer: The air increases in temperature due to internal work done on the air molecules, $W$.
The small number of nuclear decays within the object decreases the rest mass of the falling object.
The chemical energy of the object increases in order to compensate for the decrease in gravitational potential energy.
The air increases in temperature due to heat exchange, $Q$.
The Earth's kinetic energy increases in order to compensate for the decrease in potential energy.

questions.question: A block of mass $10 \mathrm{~kg}$ is being pulled across the floor at constant velocity by a rope. The tension in the rope is $20 \mathrm{~N}$ and the rope is at an angle of $25\degree$ above the horizontal. Find the force that the floor exerts on the block. ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/w3vT5IUenilK0HZMSHhbz)

A proton and an electron are far apart at rest. An external agent brings the electron and proton closer together and then holds them at rest. Which statement is correct about the work done by the external agent?

choices.answer: The work done in this case is zero because the proton and the electron will spontaneously come close to each other even without any external force.

questions.question: A car is about to make a turn at $v=3 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ such that the radius of the kissing circle at the turn is $10 \mathrm{~m}$. What should the minimum coefficient of friction be so that the car does not slip on the road?

choices.answer: One must know the mass of the car to answer the question.

questions.question: $110$ grams of boiling water are poured into an aluminum pan whose mass is $1000$ grams. The initial temperature of the water is $100 \degree \mathrm{C}$, with a heat capacity of $4.2 \frac{J}{gram \cdot K}$. The aluminum plan has an initial temperature of $24 \degree \mathrm{C}$ with a heat capacity of $0.9\frac{J}{gram \cdot K}$. After a while, the water and pan come to a common temperature. What is that temperature?

The figure below is a graph of the energy of a system of a planet interacting with a star. The gravitational potential energy $\mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{g}}$ is shown as the thick curve, and plotted along the vertical axis are various values of $\mathrm{K}+\mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{g}}$. Suppose that $\mathrm{K}+\mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{g}}$ of the system is $\mathrm{A}$. Find all of the true statements below.

1. The potential energy of the system decreases as the planet moves from $\mathrm{r}_{1}$ to $\mathrm{r}_{2}$. 
2. The potential energy of the system increases as the planet moves from $\mathrm{r}_{1}$ to $\mathrm{r}_{2}$. 
3. When the separation between the two bodies is $\mathrm{r}_{2}$, the kinetic energy of the system is $\mathrm{A}-\mathrm{B}$. 
4. The system is a bound system; the planet can never escape.
5. The path traced by this orbiting system is a circle. 
6. When the separation between the two bodies is $\mathrm{r}_{1}$, the kinetic energy of the system is $\mathrm{B}-\mathrm{C}$.

 ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/t2bsIUIL8K0Rr-SSjY0J2)

Starting from each of the locations, A-F, the comet advances in the next instant along its orbit. What is the sign of the work done on the comet by the star at different points in the orbit?
 ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/qQnAQ3Hr5Flyaoe9Tx74i)

choices.answer: No work is done on the comet by the star

questions.question:
A Ferris wheel is a vertical, circular amusement ride with radius, $R=\mathbf{1 0} \mathrm{m}$. Riders sit on seats that swivel to remain horizontal. The Ferris wheel rotates so that riders move at a constant speed, $v=5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. Consider a rider whose mass, $m=\mathbf{6 0} \mathrm{kg}$. Assume that the acceleration due to gravity, $g=\mathbf{1 0} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$.

How much work does the force exerted by the seat do on the rider as they move from point $H$ to point $B$ ? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/wkoHeYj6CV7qkVzOkA-GZ)

choices.answer: None of the above, because the rider's speed does not change.

questions.question:
A space craft, mass $100 \mathrm{~kg}$ is in outer space at location $\langle1,2,5\rangle \mathrm{~m}$ moving at an initial speed of $2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. One set of thrusters are now turned on and exert a constant force $\langle -100,200,0 \rangle \mathrm{~N}$ until the object reaches location $\langle 2,3,5 \rangle \mathrm{~m}$. At this point, these thrusters are turned off, and another set of thrusters are turned on which exert a constant force $\langle 200,-100,0 \rangle \mathrm{~N}$ until the space craft reaches $\langle 5,4,5 \rangle \mathrm{~m}$.

What is the speed of the space craft at the final location?

An ice block of mass $m$ is initially at rest at location $1$ on a smooth semicircular track in a vertical plane. A little later it is sliding through location $2$.

What is the speed, $v$ of the ice block at location $2$ ?
 ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/X3IvrbNV16AkKq51GlwLL)

An ice block of mass $m$ is initially at rest at location $1$ on a smooth semicircular track in a vertical plane. A little later it is sliding through location $2$.

What is the magnitude of the normal force, $F_{N}$ exerted on the block by the ice surface at point $2$?
 ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/ddF2uxedpqgzo-gvT_heK)

A radioactive nucleus of mass $M_{1}$ is at rest when it decays into an alpha particle (He-4 nucleus), mass $M_{\alpha}$, and a new nucleus, mass $M_{2}$. When the alpha particle and the new nucleus have moved far away from each other (so that the electric potential energy of the final alpha-nucleus system is negligible),

Which of the following represents the sum of the kinetic energies of the alpha particle and the new nucleus?

The figure below is a graph of the energy of a system consisting of a planet interacting with a star. The gravitational potential energy $U$ is shown as the thick curve. The thick horizontal lines represent $K$ + $U$. Suppose that when distance from the star to the planet is $r_{1}$, $K$ + $U$ = $A$. Find ALL of the TRUE statements from among statements 1 through 5 below.

1. $K$ decreases as the distance from star to planet changes from $r_{1}$to $r_{2}$
2. $K$ increases as the distance from star to planet changes from $r_{1}$ to $r_{2}$
3. When the distance from star to planet is $r_{2}$, $K$ = $A$ − $B$. 
4. The system is a bound system; the planet can never escape. 
5. When the distance from star to planet is $r_{1}$, $K$ = $B$ − $C$. ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/aBJFjHB5_zag0QqESDVTA)

Three protons, each of mass $\boldsymbol{m}$ and charge $+\boldsymbol{e}$, are initially held at the corners of a triangle that is $\boldsymbol{d}$ on a side. They are then released from rest.

Which of the following equations will you need to solve to determine the speed $v$ of each proton, when the protons are very far apart?

An object attached to a spring oscillates back and forth on an incline plane. The x-axis is parallel to the incline plane. The equilibrium position is $x$ = 0, and the positive x-axis is in the direction of stretching. At $t$ = 0, the object is released from the compressed spring position. 
Which graphs represents the position, $x$($t$) and velocity, $v_{x}$($t$) of the object?

A motionless light vertical hanging spring, stiffness constant $k_{S}$ has a relaxed length, $L_{0}$. A mass, $M$ is attached to the end of the spring and comes to equilibrium. With the mass and spring at rest, you very slowly pull down on the mass so that the spring stretches an additional length, $s_{i}$. At that point, you give the mass an upward initial speed, $v_{i}$.

Which of the following equations will you need to solve to determine the maximum compression, $s_{max}$, of the spring relative to the equilibrium position? Consider the spring, 
mass and Earth as the system. ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/SMnwFInn8GxQ_cXwVVIw-)

Starting from rest, a woman lifts a barbell of mass $\boldsymbol{m}$ with a constant force of $\boldsymbol{F}$ Newtons through a distance of $\boldsymbol{h}$ meters, at which point she is still lifting, and the barbell has acquired a speed of $\boldsymbol{v} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$.

Let $E_{\text {woman }}$ stand for the internal energy of the woman.

For the system consisting of the woman + barbell + Earth, which equation below is the correct application of the energy principle from the initial state with the barbell at rest to the final state with the barbell having moved upward a distance $\boldsymbol{h}$ and has a speed $\boldsymbol{v}$ ?

choices.answer: $\Delta E_{\text {woman }}+\left(\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}-0\right)+(m g h-0)=F h$
$\Delta E_{\text {woman }}+\left(0-\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}\right)+(0-m g h)=F h$

questions.question:
A block of mass $M_{A}$ and specific heat $C_{A}$ has an initial temperature of $T_{A}$. It is brought into thermal contact with a second block of mass $M_{B}$ and specific heat $C_{B}$ at temperature $T_{B}$.

Which equation should you solve to find the final equilibrium temperature $T$ ?

In a rough attempt to repeat Joule's famous experiment you begin with $1 \mathrm{~k g}$ of water at room temperature in a not very well insulated container. You stir the water until a thermometer shows that its temperature increased by $ 1 \mathrm{~K}$. In the process you did $5000 \mathrm{~J}$ of work on the water by stirring it.

What is the magnitude of the energy transfer, $|{Q}|$, from the water to its surroundings due to a temperature difference that occurred while you stirred? Note: the specific heat capacity of water is $4200 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{K}$.

A perfectly insulated house has a volume of $500 \mathrm{~m}^{3}$ and air temperature $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. You bring in a closed bucket of $10 \mathrm{~kg}$ water at almost $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.

What will the approximate temperature be in the house after equilibration?

Use specific heat of water $=4200 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{K} / \mathrm{kg}$, specific heat of air $=1000 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{K} / \mathrm{kg}$, and density of air = $1.2 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}$.

A single falling coffee filter quickly reaches a constant terminal speed. At this speed, how does the magnitude of the force due to air resistance, $\left|\vec{F}_{\text {air }}\right|$ compare with the magnitude of the force due to gravity, $\left|\vec{F}_{\text {grav }}\right|$ ?

choices.answer: The answer depends on other factors not provided

questions.question:
A spring of stiffness, $k_{s}$ and un-stretched length, $L_{0}$ is placed vertically on a horizontal surface. A block of mass $M$ is initially held at rest pressing down on the  top of the spring, such that the compressed length of the spring is $L$. The block is in contact with, but not attached to the spring, so when you release the block, the spring pushes it up all the way to the top of the top of the un-stretched length of the spring, at which point it is launched into the air.

Three students present statements about how to find the speed $v_{0}$ at which the block is launched into the air at the top of the spring. Which is correct?

Amy: You choose the block as the system and Earth and spring as the surroundings and your equation is: $\left(\frac{1}{2} M v_{0}^{2}-0\right)=-M g\left(L_{0}-L\right)+\frac{1}{2} k_{s}\left(L_{0}-L\right)^{2}$

Beth: You choose the block and spring as the system and Earth as the surroundings and your equation is : $\left(\frac{1}{2} M v_{0}^{2}-0\right)+\left(0-\frac{1}{2} k_{s}\left(L_{0}-L\right)^{2}\right)=-M g\left(L_{0}-L\right)$

Cathy: You choose the block, spring, and Earth in the system, and nothing in the surroundings, then your equation is: $\left(\frac{1}{2} M v_{0}^{2}-0\right)+M g\left(L_{0}-L\right)=\frac{1}{2} k_{s}\left(L_{0}-L\right)^{2}$ ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/UFk92bI4GjZ5uOJjjlvWK)

choices.answer: Amy is correct, but Beth and Cathy are wrong.
Beth is correct, but Amy and Cathy are wrong.
Cathy is correct, but Amy and Beth are wrong.
Both Amy and Beth are correct, Cathy is wrong.

What is the maximum height, $h_{\max }$ (relative to the top of the uncompressed spring) achieved by the block before it starts to come down again?

A spring of stiffness, $k_{s}$ and un-stretched length, $L_{0}$ is placed vertically on a horizontal surface. What is the time $t_{\max }$ after it is launched, for the block to reach the highest point on its flight?

Your friend, mass $m$ jumps up from a crouched position to a vertical standing position, such that their center of mass moves vertically upward through height $h$. During this process, the point of contact between your friend’s feet and the ground is stationary. Your friend experiences a normal force $F_{n}$ acting upward at the point of contact between the feet and the ground. Your friend’s change in internal energy in the 
process is $\Delta E_{int}$ and their change in kinetic energy due to their torso moving relative to the center of mass is $\Delta K_{rel}$

Which of the following equations represents the energy principle of the point particle system as applied to your friend from the initial to the final positions shown above? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/WgPKvwudItKQk_GIbiwOI)

Your friend, mass $m$ jumps up from a crouched position to a vertical standing position, such that their center of mass moves vertically upward through height $h$. During this process, the point of contact between your friend’s feet and the ground is stationary. Your friend experiences a normal force $F_{n}$ acting upward at the point of contact between the feet and the ground. Your friend’s change in internal energy in the 
process is $\Delta E_{int}$ and their change in kinetic energy due to their torso moving relative to the center of mass is $\Delta K_{rel}$

Which of the following equations represents the energy principle of the extended system as applied to your friend from the initial to the final positions shown above? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/T6SpSHUZ9-v1noqo1HTrc)

You, mass $M$ hang by your hands from a tree limb that is a height $L$ above the ground, with your center of mass a height $h$ above the ground, and your feet a height $d$ above the ground. You then let yourself fall. You absorb the shock by bending your knees, ending up momentarily at rest in a crouched position with your center of mass a height $b$ above the ground.

What is your kinetic energy at the instant your feet first touch the ground?

You, mass $M$ hang by your hands from a tree limb that is a height $L$ above the ground, with your center of mass a height $h$ above the ground, and your feet a height $d$ above the ground. You then let yourself fall. You absorb the shock by bending your knees, ending up momentarily at rest in a crouched position with your center of mass a height $b$ above the ground.

What is the change in internal energy in your body from the initial to final position? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/5Mkp26KBRGrZq-JQW9U32)

Using a string, you pull a $2.0-\mathrm{kg}$ box along a nearly frictionless table with a constant force of $100 \mathrm{~N}$, starting from rest. The box is full of liquid and is a cube of dimensions $1 \mathrm{~m} \times 1 \mathrm{~m} \times 1 \mathrm{~m}$. The center of mass of the system is initially located at $r_{C M i}=\langle 0.5,0.5,0\rangle \mathrm{m}$ relative to the left, lower corner of the box. At some time later, your hand has pulled through a distance of $2 \mathrm{~m}$, and the center of mass has shifted to $r_{C M f}=\langle 2.25,0.5,0\rangle$. The fluid and box is defined as "the system." There is no energy transferred thermally between the system and its surroundings.

What is the change in internal energy of the system? [Hint: You will first need to find the change in translational kinetic energy of the system.]

A rod of length $L$ and negligible mass is attached to a uniform disk of mass $M$ and radius $R$. A string is wrapped around the disk, and you pull on the string with a constant magnitude force $F$.

Two small balls each of mass $m$ slide along the rod with negligible friction. The apparatus starts from rest, and when the center of the disk has moved a distance $d$, a length of string $s$ has come off the disk, and the balls have collided with the ends of the rod and stuck there. The apparatus slides on a nearly frictionless table.

What is the angular speed, $\omega$ of the disk at this instant?

Note: The moment of inertia of a disk is $I=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}$. ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/SY_BRv1dpOjBRClMrp33n)

String is wrapped around an object of mass $M$ and moment of inertia $I$. With your hand you pull the string straight up with some constant force $F$ such that the center of the object does not move up or down, but the object spins faster and faster. When your hand is a height $y_{0}$ above the floor, the object has an angular speed of $\omega_{0}$.


What is the angular speed, $\omega$ of the object, when your hand has risen to a height $y=y_{0}+$ $\Delta y$ above the floor?

Two identical masses on a frictionless surface are connected to each other with a spring. The initial and final configurations of the masses are shown in the figure. Initially, the spring is at its equilibrium length. The rightmost mass is pulled with a force $F=100 \mathrm{~N}$ to the right.

What is the change in translational kinetic energy of the system from the initial to the final position? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/usv1pjSru8dhjidg4yBbX)

Two identical masses on a frictionless surface are connected to each other with a spring. The initial and final configurations of the masses are shown in the figure. Initially, the spring is at its equilibrium length. The rightmost mass is pulled with a force $F=100 \mathrm{~N}$ to the right.

What is the change in internal energy of the system from the initial to the final position? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/BTciZMu1JX6faPWrXDhvZ)

Four objects of the same mass, $M$ are initially at rest and positioned as shown on an inclined plane of height $h$. The "particle" is a flat, slippery object that can slide down the plane without friction. The other objects, all having the same radius, $R$ are a solid cylinder, a hoop and a solid sphere that roll down the plane without slipping.

Note: 
$I_{\text {hoop }}=M R^{2}$
$I_{\text {cylinder }}=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}$
$I_{\text {sphere }}=\frac{2}{5} M R^{2}$

If they are all released at the same time, in what order (first to last) will the objects reach the finish line? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/-MMu-p6b5UUnqK8pOKsKl)

A vehicle travels along a circular path as shown in the figure. From $A$ to $B$, the vehicle maintains a constant speed of $4 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, from $B$ to $C, 8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, and from $C$ to $D, 12 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$.

What is the average speed of the vehicle in traveling from $A$ to $D$ ? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/q1.png)

A small space probe of mass $\mathrm{m}=1000\mathrm{~kg}$  is launched from a space station in deep space. The space station exerts negligible gravitational force on the space probe. At time $\mathrm{t}=0$ when the initial position of the space probe (relative to the space station) is $\langle100,200,0\rangle \mathrm{~m}$, and it’s velocity (relative to the space station) is $\langle200,300,0\rangle \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, the spaceprobe turns on its thrusters that exert a constant force of $\langle4000,-5000,0\rangle \mathrm{~N}$.

Using a time step of $1$ second, determine the velocity of the space probe (relative to the space station) after two time steps, i.e. at $\mathrm{t}=2$ seconds.

A small space probe of mass $\mathrm{m}=1000\mathrm{~kg}$  is launched from a space station in deep space. The space station exerts negligible gravitational force on the space probe. At time $\mathrm{t}=0$ when the initial position of the space probe (relative to the space station) is $\langle100,200,0\rangle \mathrm{~m}$, and it’s velocity (relative to the space station) is $\langle200,300,0\rangle \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, the spaceprobe turns on its thrusters that exert a constant force of $\langle4000,-5000,0\rangle \mathrm{~N}$.

Using a time step of $1$ second, determine the position of the space probe (relative to the space station) after two time steps, i.e. at $\mathrm{t}=2$ seconds.

When the puck reaches location $2$ it is struck hard by a hockey stick; the contact lasts a very short time. It then travels from $2$ to $3$ at nearly constant momentum. Making the very rough approximation that the large force that the barrier exerts on the car is approximately constant during contact, determine the approximate magnitude of this force? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/q5.png)

A car traverses the course as shown, which consists of two semicircular paths, $A-B$ (radius 2R) and $\mathrm{B}-\mathrm{C}$ (radius R) as shown in the figure below. The speed of the car increases as it traverses the course, such that at point $1$ shown, its speed is $v$ and at point $2$, its speed is $2 v$ respectively.

How does the transverse component of the net force $\left|\vec{F}_{n e t, \perp}\right|$ on the car, compare at the two points? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/q12.png)

choices.answer: $\left|\vec{F}_{n e t, \perp}\right|$ at point $2$ is quarter of $\left|\vec{F}_{n e t, \perp}\right|$ at point $1$.
$\left|\vec{F}_{n e t, \perp}\right|$ at point $2$ is half of $\left|\vec{F}_{n e t, \perp}\right|$ at point $1$.
$\left|\vec{F}_{\text {net }, \perp}\right|$ at point $2$ is twice $\left|\vec{F}_{\text {net }, \perp}\right|$ at point $1$.
$\left|\vec{F}_{n e t, \perp}\right|$ at point $2$ is four times $\left|\vec{F}_{n e t, \perp}\right|$ at point $1$.
$\left|\vec{F}_{n e t, \perp}\right|$ at point $2$ is eight times $\left|\vec{F}_{n e t, \perp}\right|$ at point $1$.
